  "article_text": [
    "the binomial edge ideal of a graph was introduced in @xcite , and @xcite at about the same time .",
    "let @xmath1 be a finite simple graph with vertex set @xmath2 $ ] and edge set @xmath3 .",
    "also , let @xmath4 $ ] be the polynomial ring over a field @xmath5 .",
    "then the * binomial edge ideal * of @xmath1 in @xmath6 , denoted by @xmath7 , is generated by binomials @xmath8 , where @xmath9 and @xmath10 . also , one could see this ideal as an ideal generated by a collection of 2-minors of a @xmath11-matrix whose entries are all indeterminates .",
    "many of the algebraic properties of such ideals were studied in @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite , @xcite and @xcite . in @xcite",
    ", the authors introduced the binomial edge ideal of a pair of graphs , as a generalization of the binomial edge ideal of a graph .",
    "let @xmath12 be a graph on the vertex set @xmath13 $ ] and @xmath14 a graph on the vertex set @xmath2 $ ] , and let @xmath15 be an @xmath16-matrix of indeterminates .",
    "let @xmath17 $ ] be the polynomial ring in the variables @xmath18 , where @xmath19 and @xmath20 .",
    "let @xmath21 for some @xmath22 and @xmath23 for some @xmath24 . to the pair @xmath25",
    ", the following @xmath26-minor of @xmath27 is assigned : @xmath28=x_{it}x_{jl}-x_{il}x_{jt}.\\ ] ] then , the ideal @xmath29 is called the * binomial edge ideal of the pair * @xmath30 .",
    "some properties of this ideal were studied in @xcite . note that",
    "if @xmath12 is just an edge , then @xmath31 is isomorphic to @xmath32 .    in @xcite",
    ", the authors posed a question about the castelnuovo - mumford regularity of the binomial edge ideal of graphs , which is if @xmath33 , where @xmath34 is the number of maximal cliques of @xmath1 .",
    "they also answered this question for closed graphs , in @xcite . in @xcite",
    ", the authors gained an upper bound for the regularity of the binomial edge ideal of a graph on @xmath35 vertices .",
    "they showed that @xmath36 .",
    "they also posed a conjecture which is @xmath37 , whenever @xmath1 is not @xmath38 , the path over @xmath35 vertices . in this paper , we investigate about the regularity of the binomial edge ideals and especially these two problems .",
    "this paper is organized as follows . in section  [ preliminaries ]",
    ", we pose some definitions , facts and notation which will be used throughout the paper . in section  [ the castelnuovo - mumford regularity of binomial edge ideals ] , we show that the conjecture of matsuda and murai is true for every graph which has a cut edge or a simplicial vertex .",
    "hence , we prove this conjecture for all chordal graphs .",
    "we also show that the regularity of the binomial edge ideal of the join of two graphs @xmath12 and @xmath14 ( not both complete ) is equal to @xmath39 . applying this fact",
    ", we prove the conjecture of matsuda and murai , in the case of join of graphs , and hence for complete @xmath0-partite graphs . then , we generalize some results of schenzel and zafar about complete @xmath0-partite graphs . using a similar discussion as one appeared in @xcite",
    ", we prove that the conjecture due to the authors is true for a class of chordal graphs including block graphs , which we call them `` generalized block graphs '' .",
    "hence , we extend the recent results of ene and zarojanu about block graphs .    throughout the paper ,",
    "we mean by a graph @xmath1 , a simple graph .",
    "moreover , if @xmath40 is the vertex set of @xmath1 ( which contains @xmath35 elements ) , then , for simplicity , we denote it by @xmath2 $ ] .",
    "in this section , we review some notions and facts around graphs and binomial ideals associated to graphs , which we need throughout .    in @xcite , the authors determined all graphs whose binomial edge ideal have a grbner basis with respect to the lexicographic order induced by @xmath41 , and called this class of graphs , * closed graphs*. there are also some combinatorial descriptions for these graphs , for example in @xcite , the authors proved that a graph @xmath1 is closed if and only if there exists a labeling of @xmath1 such that all facets of @xmath42 are intervals @xmath43\\subseteq [ n]$ ] . here , @xmath42 is the clique complex of @xmath1 , the simplicial complex whose facets are the vertex sets of the maximal cliques of @xmath1 .",
    "we say that a vertex of @xmath1 is a * free vertex * , if it is a free vertex of the simplicial complex @xmath42 , i.e. it is just contained in one facet of @xmath42 .",
    "this is equivalent to say that such a vertex @xmath44 has this property that @xmath45 induces a complete subgraph of @xmath1 , and the vertex @xmath44 is also called a * simplicial vertex*. by @xmath45 , we mean the set of all neighbors ( i.e. adjacent vertices ) of the vertex @xmath44 in @xmath1 .",
    "let @xmath1 and @xmath46 be two graphs on @xmath13 $ ] and @xmath2 $ ] , respectively .",
    "we denote by @xmath47 , the _",
    "join _ ( product ) of two graphs @xmath1 and @xmath46 , that is the graph with vertex set @xmath13\\cup [ n]$ ] , and the edge set @xmath48,~w\\in [ n]\\}$ ] . in particular ,",
    "the cone of a vertex @xmath44 on a graph @xmath1 is defined to be their join , that is @xmath49 , and is sometimes denoted by @xmath50 .",
    "let @xmath51 be a set .",
    "to simplify our notation throughout this paper , we introduce the join of two collection of subsets of @xmath51 , @xmath52 and @xmath53 , denoted by @xmath54 , as @xmath55 .",
    "if @xmath56 are collections of subsets of @xmath51 , then we denote their join , by @xmath57 .",
    "let @xmath1 be a graph and @xmath58 an edge of it .",
    "then vertices @xmath44 and @xmath59 are called the endpoints of @xmath60 . if @xmath61 is a set of edges of @xmath1 , then by @xmath62 , we mean the graph on the same vertex set as @xmath1 in which the edges @xmath63 are omitted . here",
    ", we simply write @xmath64 , instead of @xmath65 . an edge @xmath60 of @xmath1 whose deletion from the graph , implies a graph with more connected components than @xmath1 , is called a * cut edge * of @xmath1 .",
    "now , we recall a notation from @xcite .",
    "if @xmath66 are two vertices of a graph @xmath67 and @xmath58 is not an edge of @xmath1 , then @xmath68 is defined to be the graph on the vertex set @xmath51 , and the edge set @xmath69 .    a vertex @xmath44 of @xmath1 whose deletion from the graph , implies a graph with more connected components than @xmath1 , is called a * cut point * of @xmath1 .",
    "a * nonseparable * graph is a connected and nontrivial graph with no cut points",
    ". a * block * of a graph is a maximal nonseparable subgraph of it .",
    "a * block graph * is a connected graph whose blocks are complete graphs ( see @xcite for more information in this topic ) .",
    "a disconnected graph is called a block graph , if all of its connected components are block graphs .",
    "one can see that a graph @xmath1 is a block graph if and only if it is a chordal graph in which every two maximal cliques have at most one vertex in common .",
    "this class was considered in  ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem  1.1 ) . here",
    ", we introduce a class of chordal graphs including block graphs : let @xmath1 be a connected chordal graph such that for every three maximal cliques of @xmath1 which have a nonempty intersection , the intersection of each pair of them is the same . in other words , @xmath1 has the property that for every @xmath70 , if @xmath71 , then @xmath72 . we call @xmath1 , a * generalized block * graph . a disconnected graph is called a generalized block graph , if all of its connected components are generalized block graphs . by the above , it is clear that a block graph is also a generalized block graph .",
    "hence , a tree is also a generalized block graph . the graph depicted in figure",
    "[ generalized ] is a generalized block graph , which is not a block graph .",
    "[ generalized ]    suppose that @xmath1 is a graph on @xmath2 $ ] .",

    "if @xmath288 , then @xmath1 is the join of two graphs each consisting of some isolated vertices .",
    "so , the regularity of the binomial edge ideal of each of them is @xmath289 .",
    "thus , by theorem  [ reg - join ] , we have @xmath287 . now",
    ", suppose that @xmath290 and the result is true for every complete @xmath291-partite graph which is not complete .",
    "let @xmath292 be the partition of the vertices of @xmath1 to @xmath0 parts .",
    "hence , we have @xmath293 , and @xmath294 is a complete @xmath291-partite graph . if @xmath294 is a complete graph , then @xmath295 , since , otherwise , @xmath1 is a complete graph , a contradiction .",
    "so , by theorem  [ reg - join ] , @xmath287 .",
    "if @xmath294 is not complete , then by the induction hypothesis , we have @xmath296 . thus , again by theorem",
    "[ reg - join ] , the result follows .",
    "now , we go to the proof of our main theorems . + _ proof of theorem  [ main ] . _",
    "if @xmath1 is a disconnected graph with @xmath297 connected components @xmath221 , over @xmath298 vertices , respectively , then we have @xmath299 . by theorem  [ matsuda - murai ] , we have @xmath300 .",
    "so that @xmath301 , since @xmath297 .",
    "so , the result follows in this case . now , suppose that @xmath1 has a cut edge @xmath60 .",
    "then , @xmath64 is disconnected and hence @xmath173 . on the other hand , @xmath175 has two connected components , say @xmath12 and @xmath14 , which both have a simplicial vertex .",
    "so that conjecture  a is true for both of them , by theorem  [ chordal ] .",
    "note that @xmath12 and @xmath14 are not both paths , as @xmath1 is not .",
    "thus , as mentioned above , we have @xmath302 .",
    "so , by proposition  [ colon2 ] , we get the result in this case too . now , combining theorem  [ reg - chordal ] , theorem  [ reg - join ] and ( * ? ? ?",
    "* corollary  3.8 ) we get the result .",
    "@xmath139 + _ proof of theorem  [ main2 ] .",
    "_ by theorem  [ construction ] , theorem  [ kiani - saeedi ] and theorem  [ reg - generalized ] , the result follows .",
    "@xmath139 + * acknowledgments : * the authors would like to thank professor j. herzog for some useful comments .",
    "also , the authors would like to thank to the institute for research in fundamental sciences ( ipm ) for financial support .",
    "the research of the first author was in part supported by a grant from ipm ( no .",
    "92050220 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> we prove two recent conjectures on some upper bounds for the castelnuovo - mumford regularity of the binomial edge ideals of some different classes of graphs . </S>",
    "<S> we prove the conjecture of matsuda and murai for graphs which has a cut edge or a simplicial vertex , and hence for chordal graphs . </S>",
    "<S> we determine the regularity of the binomial edge ideal of the join of graphs in terms of the regularity of the original graphs , and consequently prove the conjecture of matsuda and murai for such a graph , and hence for complete @xmath0-partite graphs . </S>",
    "<S> we also generalize some results of schenzel and zafar about complete @xmath0-partite graphs . </S>",
    "<S> we also prove the conjecture due to the authors for a class of chordal graphs . </S>"
  ]
}
